In the UK, "LaserVision" was used to denote discs with analog sound, while "LaserDisc" referred to those with digital audio.

Both formats utilized EFM encoding for digital sound, mirroring CD technology. Notably, LaserDisc pioneered the inclusion of Dolby Digital (AC-3) and DTS audio, later becoming commonplace on DVDs. Star Wars: Episode I – The Phantom Menace (1999) stands out as an early example, featuring 6.1-channel Dolby Digital EX Surround on its Japanese LaserDisc release.

Unlike DVDs, which carry Dolby Digital in a digital format, LaserDisc encoded Dolby Digital as a frequency-modulated signal within a track typically reserved for analog audio. The demodulator was essential for converting the 2.88 MHz modulated AC-3 information into a 384 kbit/s signal suitable for the decoder.

When DTS audio was present on a disc, it replaced the digital audio tracks.  A DTS-compatible digital connection to a DTS decoder was all that was needed to enjoy DTS sound.

Richard Feynman, through his insightful diagrams of particles interacting in spacetime, revolutionized our understanding of physics. He proposed a model, now known as the parton model, to explain the strong interactions governing the scattering of nucleons. This model, developed independently of Murray Gell-Mann's quark model, initially faced skepticism from the latter, who even referred to Feynman's partons as "put-ons."

During the mid-1960s, the existence of quarks was heavily debated. Physicists believed they might be merely a mathematical tool to describe symmetry, not actual particles. This uncertainty stemmed from the analysis of the Omega-minus particle, which, if composed of three identical strange quarks, defied statistical predictions.

The tide turned in the late 1960s with groundbreaking experiments at the Stanford Linear Accelerator. These deep inelastic scattering experiments, analogous to Rutherford's alpha particle scattering experiment, revealed that nucleons, composed of protons and neutrons, contained point-like particles that scattered electrons. This finding naturally led to the identification of these particles as quarks.

Feynman's parton model sought to interpret these experimental results without introducing additional hypotheses.  Crucially, the data showed that approximately 45% of the energy-momentum within a nucleon was carried by electrically neutral particles. These particles are now understood to be gluons, the force carriers responsible for binding quarks together and possessing the three-valued color quantum number, which elegantly resolved the Omega-minus problem.

It's important to note that Feynman never rejected the quark model. In fact, when the fifth quark was discovered in 1977, he immediately recognized its implications, predicting the existence of a sixth quark, which was subsequently found after his death.

In late 1203, King John of England launched a desperate attempt to break Philip II of France's siege of Château Gaillard, a strategically crucial fortress guarding the eastern flank of Normandy.  John envisioned a bold, two-pronged assault involving both land and naval forces, a daring strategy considered innovative by many historians, though perhaps overly ambitious for the technological limitations of the time.  

However, Philip's forces thwarted John's relief effort, forcing him to retreat to Brittany. There, John unleashed a campaign of devastation, aiming to lure Philip away from Normandy. While successful in wreaking havoc in Brittany, John failed to divert Philip's primary objective: the conquest of eastern Normandy.

Historians debate the military acumen John displayed during this campaign. While some argue his performance was adequate, most modern scholars believe it lacked brilliance.

John's situation grew increasingly precarious. Philip had spent years cultivating the fertile lands of eastern Normandy, while John's authority in the south had been weakened years earlier by his predecessor, Richard I, who had granted away vital castles. John's reliance on unreliable routier mercenaries in central Normandy further eroded his support, paving the way for a swift collapse of Angevin power.

By December, John was forced to retreat across the English Channel, ordering the construction of a new defensive line west of Château Gaillard. But even this proved insufficient. In March 1204, Château Gaillard fell to Philip's forces.

Adding to John's woes, his mother, Eleanor of Aquitaine, died the following month. This personal tragedy threatened to unravel the extensive Angevin alliances in southern France.

Philip seized this opportunity, maneuvering his forces around the new defensive line and advancing into the heart of the Duchy of Normandy.  Facing little resistance, he swiftly conquered Normandy by August.  His victory emboldened him further, driving south to seize Anjou and Poitou as well. John's sole remaining continental possession was reduced to the Duchy of Aquitaine.

A 2013 study, conducted by a team led by Martin B. Richards of the University of Huddersfield in England, re-examined the origins of Ashkenazi Jewish maternal lineages. This study, focusing on Ashkenazi mitochondrial DNA, offered compelling evidence supporting the pre-2006 hypothesis of an ancient European origin for Ashkenazi ancestry. 

Unlike the 2006 Behar study, which analyzed only 1,000 DNA units, Richards' team comprehensively examined the full 16,600 units composing mitochondrial DNA.  Their research revealed that the four primary female Ashkenazi founders had ancestral lineages established in Europe between 10,000 and 20,000 years ago. The majority of the remaining minor founders also exhibited deep European ancestry.

The study concluded that the vast majority of Ashkenazi maternal lineages were not introduced from the Near East (disproving the Israelite origin theory) nor recruited from the Caucasus region (refuting the Khazar origin theory). Instead, these lineages were assimilated within Europe, primarily originating from Italian and Old French populations.

Richards explicitly stated that "[N]one [of the mtDNA] came from the North Caucasus," debunking the longstanding but unsubstantiated theory that Ashkenazi Jews primarily descended from the Khazar Kingdom.

The 2013 study estimated that 80 percent of Ashkenazi maternal ancestry can be traced to indigenous European women, with only 8 percent originating from the Near East. The remaining 12 percent remains  to be fully elucidated.

The 1912 Salon d'Automne showcased a groundbreaking architectural installation, the Maison Cubiste (Cubist House), conceived by Raymond Duchamp-Villon and André Mare with the collaboration of a group of artists.  

This installation coincided with the writing of "Cubisme" by Metzinger and Gleizes, who emphasized the autonomy of art, arguing that decorative considerations should not dictate its essence. They viewed decorative work as the antithesis of true art, stating that a genuine artwork possesses its own inherent meaning and can exist independently of its surroundings. 

Christopher Green explains that Mare's architectural ensembles were chosen because they granted Cubist artworks the freedom to stand alone, creating a dialogue of contrasts. This collaboration involved prominent figures like Gleizes and Metzinger, Marie Laurencin, the Duchamp brothers (Raymond designed the facade), and Mare's longtime friends, Léger and Roger La Fresnaye. 

The Maison Cubiste was a fully furnished house, complete with a staircase, wrought iron banisters, a living room, the Salon Bourgeois, which displayed paintings by Marcel Duchamp, Metzinger, Gleizes, Laurencin, and Léger, and a bedroom. It epitomized L'art décoratif, showcasing Cubist art within the comfort and style of modern bourgeois life. 

Visitors to the Salon d'Automne could walk through a full-scale plaster model of the ground floor facade, designed by Duchamp-Villon, measuring 10 by 3 meters. This architectural installation was later showcased at the 1913 Armory Show in New York, Chicago, and Boston.  In the New York catalogue, it was listed as Raymond Duchamp-Villon, number 609, and titled "Facade architecturale" (Architectural Facade).




The 1912 Salon d'Automne showcased a groundbreaking architectural installation, aptly named Maison Cubiste (Cubist House).  This collaborative project, signed by Raymond Duchamp-Villon and André Mare along with a team of artists, quickly gained notoriety. 

Coinciding with the creation of the "Maison Cubiste," Metzinger and Gleizes, in their seminal work "Cubisme," emphasized the inherent autonomy of art. They argued against prioritizing decorative considerations in artistic expression, viewing decorative work as the antithesis of true art.  Metzinger and Gleizes asserted that:

"The true picture bears its raison d'être within itself. It can be moved from a church to a drawing-room, from a museum to a study. Essentially independent, necessarily complete, it need not immediately satisfy the mind: on the contrary, it should lead it, little by little, towards the fictitious depths in which the coordinative light resides. It does not harmonize with this or that ensemble; it harmonizes with things in general, with the universe: it is an organism..."

André Mare's ensembles, characterized by their ability to provide a framework for Cubist works while preserving their individual autonomy, were deemed ideal for this project. As Christopher Green notes, these ensembles created a captivating interplay of contrasts, drawing in notable figures like Gleizes and Metzinger, Marie Laurencin, the Duchamp brothers (Raymond Duchamp-Villon's design graced the facade), and Mare's close friends, Léger and Roger La Fresnaye.

La Maison Cubiste offered a fully furnished interior, complete with a staircase, wrought iron banisters, a living room (dubbed the Salon Bourgeois), and a bedroom.  The Salon Bourgeois displayed paintings by prominent Cubist artists, including Marcel Duchamp, Metzinger ("Woman with a Fan"), Gleizes, Laurencin, and Léger.  This ambitious project served as a compelling example of L'art décoratif, demonstrating how Cubist art could seamlessly integrate into the comforts and elegance of modern bourgeois life.

Visitors to the Salon d'Automne had the opportunity to step inside a scaled plaster model of the ground floor facade, meticulously designed by Duchamp-Villon.  Measuring a substantial 10 by 3 meters, this architectural installation was later exhibited at the prestigious 1913 Armory Show, traveling to New York, Chicago, and Boston. The New York catalogue listed Raymond Duchamp-Villon as the artist, entry number 609, and titled the work "Facade architecturale" (Architectural Façade).

rewrite_original:
In 2006, Morgan Stanley made a significant investment in Atlantic City, purchasing 20 acres of land directly north of the Showboat Casino for the development of a new, upscale casino resort with an estimated cost exceeding $2 billion. Revel Entertainment Group was selected to spearhead this ambitious project, which would become known as the Revel Casino.

However, Revel's journey was fraught with challenges. A major setback occurred in April 2010 when Morgan Stanley, the majority shareholder (owning 90% of Revel Entertainment Group), abruptly halted funding for the ongoing construction and initiated the process of selling its stake in the company. This decision cast a shadow over the project's future.

In an attempt to rescue the project, the New Jersey state legislature introduced a bill offering tax incentives to attract new investors and ensure the casino's completion. However, public opinion was divided. A poll conducted by Fairleigh Dickinson University's PublicMind in March 2010 revealed that a significant majority (60%) of voters opposed the legislation, with a substantial portion expressing strong opposition.

Despite the public resistance, Governor Chris Christie ultimately offered Revel $261 million in state tax credits as financial assistance upon the casino's opening. By March 2011, Revel had overcome its funding hurdles and made substantial progress. The exterior construction was complete, and work on the interior was underway, bringing the dream of a grand opening closer to reality.

After a soft opening in April 2012, Revel finally welcomed its guests fully in May 2012. Unfortunately, the casino faced persistent financial difficulties. Just ten months later, in February 2013, Revel filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy, with its value plummeting from an initial $2.4 billion to a mere $450 million.

Despite attempts at restructuring, Revel's financial woes persisted. It re-entered bankruptcy on June 19, 2014, and was put up for sale. However, due to a lack of suitable offers, the resort was forced to close its doors permanently on September 2, 2014, marking a sad end to a once-promising venture.

A major blow came in April 2010 when Morgan Stanley, holding a 90% stake in Revel Entertainment Group, abruptly halted funding for construction and put its investment up for sale.  

Despite the New Jersey state legislature's attempt to attract investors with tax incentives earlier that year, public opposition to the legislation was strong. A Fairleigh Dickinson University poll revealed that 60% of voters opposed the bill, with a significant portion "strongly" opposed.  Ultimately, Governor Chris Christie offered Revel $261 million in state tax credits to assist the casino upon its opening.

After securing the necessary funding, Revel completed the exterior work by March 2011 and continued interior construction.  A soft opening occurred in April 2012, followed by a full opening in May 2012.

Despite restructuring efforts, Revel's financial woes persisted, leading to a second bankruptcy filing on June 19, 2014.  The resort was put up for sale, but with no suitable bids received, it closed its doors for good on September 2, 2014.

After a period of internal division, the Australian Liberal Party faced the economic turmoil of the early 1990s recession, with unemployment peaking at 11.4% in 1992.  Within the party, former Treasurer John Howard and former Foreign Minister Andrew Peacock vied for leadership.  

In an attempt to address these challenges and chart a new course, the opposition, led by Dr. John Hewson, unveiled the "Fightback!" policy in November 1991. This 650-page document outlined a radical set of economic liberal reforms. Key proposals included:

* **Goods and Services Tax (GST):** A 15% GST was to be introduced, becoming the centerpiece of the policy.
* **Medicare Changes:**  Bulk billing for non-concession holders would be abolished, and other changes made to the healthcare system.
* **Unemployment Benefits:** A nine-month limit would be imposed on unemployment benefits.
* **Industrial Relations:**  Awards would be abolished, and changes made to labor laws.
* **Taxation:** A $13 billion personal income tax cut targeted at middle and upper income earners, along with $10 billion in government spending cuts.
* **Privatization:**  A large number of government-owned enterprises would be privatized.
* **State Payroll Taxes:**  These would be abolished.


Prime Minister Paul Keating and the Labor Party fiercely campaigned against "Fightback!", particularly the GST, which Keating framed as an attack on the working class by shifting the tax burden from direct taxation of the wealthy to indirect consumption taxes. The Montana Territory's story began on April 26, 1864, with the passage of the Organic Act by the U.S. Congress.  However, the seeds of education were sown even before its official territorial status. As families began to settle in the area, subscription schools emerged, often held in the teacher's home.

The earliest documented formal school was established at Fort Owen in the Bitterroot Valley in 1862. It served the children of soldiers and employees of the fort, as well as local Indian children. This initial school term, which commenced in early winter, concluded on February 28th, with Mr. Robinson as its instructor.

Another early subscription school opened in Virginia City in 1863, led by Thomas Dimsdale.  Here, students paid $1.75 per week for their education.

The Montana Territorial Legislative Assembly convened for its inaugural meeting in 1864.  A significant milestone was the legislature's authorization for counties to levy taxes for school purposes. This paved the way for the establishment of public schools. Madison County seized this opportunity, creating the first public school in Virginia City in 1886.

Initially scheduled to begin in January 1866, the first school year was delayed by severe weather until March.  The school year extended through the summer, finally concluding on August 17th. Sarah Raymond, a 25-year-old woman who had arrived in Virginia City by wagon train in 1865, was among the first teachers. To obtain her teaching certificate, Raymond took a test at her home and paid a $6 fee in gold dust. With the assistance of Mrs. Farley, an assistant teacher, Raymond was tasked with instructing 50 to 60 students. 




The Montana Territory came into existence on April 26, 1864, marked by the passage of the Organic Act by the U.S. government.  Prior to official territorial status, educational endeavors were already underway as families began to establish themselves in the region.  Early schools were primarily subscription schools, often held within the teacher's residence.  

A notable milestone was the establishment of the first recorded formal school at Fort Owen in the Bitterroot Valley in 1862. This school served the children of Indian tribes and employees of the fort. The inaugural term commenced in early winter and concluded on February 28th. Mr. Robinson served as the instructor.

Another early subscription school emerged in Virginia City in 1863, spearheaded by Thomas Dimsdale. Students were charged a weekly fee of $1.75 for their education.

The Montana Territorial Legislative Assembly convened for its inaugural meeting in 1864.  A significant development was the legislature's authorization for counties to levy taxes for school purposes, laying the groundwork for a public school system. The inaugural school year was initially planned to begin in January 1866, but severe weather conditions delayed its commencement until March. The school year extended through the summer, ultimately concluding on August 17th.

On June 20, 1794, Edmund Burke received a vote of thanks from the House of Commons for his significant contributions to the Hastings Trial. Subsequently, he chose to resign his seat, which was then filled by his son, Richard. Tragically, August 1794 brought the loss of Richard, to whom Burke was deeply attached.  He saw potential in his son that others didn't recognize, though this view might have been influenced by Richard's successful advocacy for Catholic emancipation.

King George III, who had grown fond of Burke due to his stance on the French Revolution, intended to elevate him to the peerage as Earl of Beaconsfield. However, the untimely death of his son prevented this honor from being bestowed, and Burke ultimately accepted only a modest pension of £2,500. 

Even this seemingly small reward drew criticism from prominent figures such as the Duke of Bedford and the Earl of Lauderdale. Burke responded with his influential "Letter to a Noble Lord" (1796), where he passionately defended his position. He asserted that his pension was a recognition of his merit, contrasting it with the Duke of Bedford's inheritance-based wealth, whose ancestor was the original recipient of the pension.  Burke pointedly remarked, “Mine was from a mild and benevolent sovereign; his from Henry the Eighth”.

Furthermore, Burke subtly alluded to the potential consequences of the revolutionaries' ideas, weaving in a description of the British constitution to underscore his concerns.  

This rewritten version maintains all the original details while employing more vivid language and clearer sentence structure.

Burke also alluded to the potential consequences of the revolutionary ideas championed by individuals like the Duke of Bedford, and included a defense of the British constitution in his letter.

Following its independence, Tajikistan descended into a devastating civil war fueled by deep-seated clan rivalries. This conflict displaced over 500,000 residents who sought refuge from persecution, economic hardship, and the promise of better opportunities in the West or other former Soviet republics.

Amidst the chaos, Emomali Rahmon emerged victorious in a 1992 presidential election, securing 58% of the vote against former prime minister Abdumalik Abdullajanov. The election, held shortly after the war's end, took place in a nation utterly ravaged by conflict, with an estimated death toll exceeding 100,000 and 1.2 million people displaced both internally and externally.

In 1997, a glimmer of hope appeared as a ceasefire agreement, brokered by Gerd D. Merrem, the United Nations' Special Representative to the Secretary General, brought an end to the hostilities. This landmark agreement, widely lauded as a successful peacekeeping initiative, allocated 30% of ministerial positions to the opposition.

However, the fragile peace was tested in subsequent elections.  The 1999 elections, which saw Rahmon re-elected with a staggering 98% of the vote, were condemned by opposition parties and international observers as deeply flawed and unfair. A similar pattern emerged in 2006, when Rahmon secured his third term with 79% of the vote, despite boycotts by several opposition parties. While observers from the Commonwealth of Independent States declared the elections legitimate, the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) voiced its criticism, citing concerns about fairness and transparency.

Further accusations of repression and censorship under Rahmon's administration arose in 2010. The OSCE alleged that the Tajik government systematically censored both domestic and foreign websites, and imposed burdensome tax inspections on independent printing houses, effectively silencing several independent newspapers.

**Tajikistan: A Nation Forged in Fire**

The heart of Central Asia, Tajikistan, became a theatre of sorrow.  Civil war ripped through its soul, factions clashing under the banner of clan loyalty.  The land itself was stained with the blood of its people, a tapestry of turmoil woven into its very fabric.

Half a million souls were driven from their homes by persecution, seeking refuge in the West or the fading light of the former Soviet republics. Poverty's grip and the allure of a brighter future propelled them, their weary feet carrying them towards the distant promise of dreams realized.

1992 marked a turning point. Emomali Rahmon emerged victorious from a bloody conflict, defeating Abdujalilov in a land scarred by war.  The election, held amidst the shadows of destruction, left a heavy toll, with over one hundred thousand lives lost, their echoes haunting the nation.

Millions of refugees scattered across the globe, seeking solace and hope amidst the ruins. In 1997, a fragile ceasefire, brokered by the United Nations, brought a semblance of peace to the war-torn land. However, the path to healing was long and arduous.

Despite the ceasefire, elections remained marred by allegations of unfairness. Rahmon consolidated his power, securing near-perfect scores in votes that many perceived as lacking legitimacy. Opposition voices were silenced or ignored, while international observers watched with a mixture of concern and skepticism.

King George V, who ascended the throne in 1910 following Edward VII, possessed a more serious demeanor than his predecessor. His reign saw a shift in emphasis from extravagant parties to official engagements and royal duties.  A series of command performances featuring renowned jazz musicians like the Original Dixieland Jazz Band (1919), Sidney Bechet, and Louis Armstrong (1932) graced the palace. Notably, the 1919 performance by the Original Dixieland Jazz Band marked the first time jazz music was performed for a head of state. This musical legacy earned the palace a 2009 nomination for a (Kind of) Blue Plaque by the Brecon Jazz Festival, recognizing its significant contribution to jazz music in the United Kingdom.

Queen Mary's influence extended to the installation of numerous new fixtures and fittings within the palace. This room, situated at the heart of the garden façade, is known for its expansive, low-ceilinged design. Queen Mary also took charge of decorating the Blue Drawing Room. This expansive room, measuring 69 feet (21 meters) in length, was formerly known as the South Drawing Room and boasts a ceiling uniquely designed by Nash, adorned with imposing gilt console brackets.
